newsitem.title: CYPRUS: Cyprus Airways pilots suspend action.
newsitem.headline: Cyprus Airways pilots suspend action.

text.p: Pilots of national carrier Cyprus Airways on Thursday backed down in a labour dispute with management which had prompted the government to warn it could withhold a guarantee for a loan sought by the airline.
Pilots union PASIPI said late on Thursday it was suspending work-to-rule measures adopted to protest over the transfer of work from Cyprus Airways to Eurocypria, its charter subsidiary.

On Monday a pilot sticking to the union guidelines landed a plane from Zurich with 153 passengers at the wrong airport on the holiday island, refusing to fly an extra 10 minutes to the proper destination.

The incident prompted a warning from Finance Minister Christodoulos Christodoulou that the government may decide to withhold its guarantee to a $30 million loan the company is due to seek later this year.
The loan is designed to replace an existing short-term loan and to carry out maintenance checks on the Cyprus Airways fleet, company officials said.
At the end of 1996, Cyprus Airways had outstanding loans of about 100 million pounds ($193 million).

Last week the Cyprus Airways group announced a preliminary consolidated pre-tax loss of 2.15 million pounds ($4.2 million) in 1996, compared to a pre-tax profit of 5.03 million pounds in 1995. The company has blamed falling load factors and increased fuel prices for the decline.
The situation in the airline is due to be discussed at the weekly cabinet meeting next week.
